user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of try_match_header:
```c
static int
try_match_header (const char *prefix,
                  size_t prefix_len,
                  char *line,
                  char **suffix)
{
  if (NULL != *suffix)
    return MHD_NO;
  while (0 != *line)
  {
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ (prefix,
                                   line,
                                   prefix_len))
    {
      *suffix = strdup (&line[prefix_len]);
      return MHD_YES;
    }
    ++line;
  }
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
*suffix = strdup (&line[prefix_len]);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: As written this call is not inherently in violation because strdup(&line[prefix_len]) is executed only after MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ returned true, which implies the prefix_len bytes starting at 'line' exist and the remainder of the string is NUL-terminated so strdup will not read past the object. A violation scenario would occur if prefix_len is greater than the remaining length of 'line' (or if MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ is faulty and returns true despite line being shorter); in that case &line[prefix_len] would point outside the bounds (or not to a NUL-terminated string) and strdup would read beyond the object bounds.
